children.name: to know about sth secret or dishonest and take part in it
be in on
children.definition: /biː ˈɪn ɒn/  informal to take part in or know all about an illegal or secret activity:có mặt, tham gia vào hoạt động gì
examples: ▪ is it true that the chief of police was in on the cover-up?
▪ jones denies being in on the plan to blow up the building.
▪ he didn’t have a clue about the surprise party, but everyone in the office was in on it.

children.name: be (a) party x
children.definition: be (a) party to formal to take part in something which is illegal or wrong: dính líu vào cái gì
examples: ▪ my clients do not want to be party to tax evasion.
▪ prosecutors proved she was in the house and was a party to the murder.

children.name: have a hand x
children.definition: have a hand in (doing) something/hæv ə ˌhænd ɪn (ˈduːɪŋ) something/  to be in some way secretly involved in something and be partly responsible for its results: nhúng tay vào chuyện gì
examples: ▪ he is a member of one of the extremist groups that may have had a hand in the murder.
▪ do they suspect the government of having a hand in it?
▪ my father may have had a hand in getting me the job.

children.name: collude x
children.definition: collude/kəˈ;uːd/  to know about and encourage something wrong that someone else is doing:cấu kết, thông đồng
examples: collude in: cấu kết, thông đồng trong chuyện gì
▪ how far can women be said to be colluding in their own lower employment status?
collude with: cấu kết, thông đồng với
▪ there have been accusations that the prime minister secretly colluded with the leaders of the regime.

children.name: to take part in an event, activity, discussion etc
take part b1
children.definition: take part to participate in sth.take partis less formal thatparticipateand is more common in everyday english :
examples: anyone who is over 18 can take part.
she wanted to take part but she was too ill.
the program teaches children about conservation, and about 30 schools are taking part.
take part in
police have arrested a number of people who took part in the riot.
nearly 500 teams took part in the competition.
she was asked to take part in a tv debate on drugs.
take an active/leading part
john has taken an active part in getting artists together for the festival.

children.name: be involved b1
children.definition: be involved to take part in an activity with asmallnumber of other people, often sthbadorillegal:
examples: ▪ choosing a school is an important decision, and both parents ought to be involved.
be involved in
▪at least three politicians are involved in the scandal.
▪ the two men have denied being involved in troy’s kidnapping and murder.
▪ roughly two-thirds of high school students are involved in volunteer community work.

children.name: participate b2
children.definition: participateformalto take part in an activity or event, especially an organized one:
examples: some members refused to participate.
there are regular class discussions, but some of the students never participate.
being a spectator wasn’t as enjoyable as participating.
participate in
everyone in the class is expected toparticipate activelyin these discussions.
they welcomed the opportunity toparticipate fullyin the life of the village.

► participateis never followed immediately by a noun, or by ‘on’ or ‘to’. say that youparticipate insomething :more people should participate in elections (not more people should participate elections).
registerin everyday english, people usually saytake partrather thanparticipate:
she refused totake part inany of the activities.

children.name: play a part b2
children.definition: play a part/role to take part in some way in an activity or piece of work, especially one which has a useful result or purpose:
examples: ▪ our goal is to make sure everyone plays a part and shares in the credit.
▪ although the budget committees guide congress’s actions on spending, every committee plays a role.
play a part/role in
▪ hart clearly played a role in the decision to change admission standards.
▪ together with the police everyone can play a part in improving the security of their neighborhood.
play an active/large/important etc part/role
▪ men now play a larger part in looking after their children.
▪ the most effective learning occurs when the child is allowed to play a more active role in the learning process.
▪ the secretary of state played a leading role in the government’s successful foreign policy.
▪ schneider played a key role in getting the organization started.

children.name: be active in b2
children.definition: be active in to actively take part in the work of an organization such as a political group or church: tham giatích cực
examples: he is very active in the church’s work with homeless people.
in school i was very active in sports and student government.
allen, who is still on the board, is no longer active in the day-to-day management of the company.

children.name: be engaged in x
children.definition: be engaged in/biː ɪnˈgeɪdʒd ɪn/ formalto be taking part in an activity, a conversation etc, especially one that continues for a long period of time: tham gia/tham dự vào
examples: ▪ the nationalists have been engaged in a bitter fifteen-year armed struggle for independence.
▪ during dinner i found myself engaged in a long complicated discussion with the doctor’s wife.

children.name: sb who takes part in sth
participant c1
children.definition: participant/pɑːʳˈtɪsɪpənt, pɑːʳˈtɪsəpənt/ formalsomeone who takes part in an organized event or activity:
examples: người tham gia, người tham dự
▪ this summer’s children’s art program had 14 participants.
▪ at the end of the conference, all the participants were asked to fill out a questionnaire.
participant in: người tham gia/tham dự trong hoạt động gì
▪reyes is an active participant in the protest movement.

children.name: involved b1
children.definition: involved/ɪnˈvɒlvdǁɪnˈvɑːlvd/  the people involved are the people who are taking part or who took part in an activity or event:
examples: tham gia, dính líu
▪ in court she gave evidence about her torture, naming the officers involved.
▪ most of the people involved have by now either died or moved away.
▪ following the riots, the university promised to discipline all those involved.

children.name: join in b1
children.definition: join in/ˌdʒɔɪn ˈɪn/  to start taking part in something that other people are already doing, especially somethingenjoyablesuch as a game, or a song:
examples: tham gia, gia nhập , nhập bọn
▪ when we get to the chorus i want everybody to join in!
▪ james joined in the discussion to say that he agreed with what had been said.
join in something: tham gia, gia nhập cái gì
▪ we all wanted to join in the fun.
join in with: tham gia/gia nhập với ai
▪ as a child, i was too shy to join in with the other children’s games.

children.name: get involved b1
children.definition: get involved/ˌget ɪnˈvɒlvdǁ-ˈvɑːlvd/  to start to take part in something, often something that will cause youproblemsortakea lot ofyourtime:
examples: tham gia/dính líu
▪ it’s a private matter between the two of them, and i don’t think we should get involved.
get involved in: tham gia/dính líu vào cái gì
▪ when did anderson first get involved in local politics?
▪ i don’t want to get involved in an argument with you on the phone.
▪ the us seemed unwilling to get involved in another war.

children.name: get in on the act x
children.definition: get in on the act/get ˌɪn ɒn ði ˈækt/  informal to start to take part in something that is already successful, especially a new type of business that other companies are already involved in: tham gia, có mặt
examples: ▪ now that our exporting business to eastern europe has grown so successful, everyone wants to get in on the act.
▪ movie theater chains are expanding rapidly, and even small local theaters are getting in on the act.

children.name: get on the bandwagon c2
children.definition: jump/climb/hop/get on the bandwagon/ˌdʒʌmp, ˌklaɪm, ˌhɒp, get ɒn ðə ˈbændwægənǁˌhɑːp-/  informal to start to take part in an activity because a lot of other people are doing it and not necessarily because you believe in it:tham gia/dính líu tới hoạt động gì
examples: ▪ more and more republicans are hopping on the tax bandwagon to attract more voters.
▪ critics of the government’s environmental policies say it has simply jumped on the bandwagon and has not done anything serious to fight pollution.

children.name: muscle in on x
children.definition: muscle in on/ˌmʌsəl ˈɪn ɒn/  informal to deliberately interfere in a plan, activity etc that other people are organizing so that you can have some of the advantages of that situation:cố ý can thiệp
examples: ▪ i’m not going to let jim muscle in on this deal - let him do his own negotiations.
▪ two men were killed when members of a rival gang tried to muscle in on their territory.

children.name: get into the spirit x
children.definition: get/enter into the spirit/ˌget, ˌentər ɪntə ðə ˈspɪrt/  to relax and take part in a party, celebration, or special occasion:tham gia (vào một bữa tiệc, buổi lễ, một dịp nào đó)
examples: ▪ this year pat decided to get into the spirit and decorate her house for halloween.
▪ although mark felt depressed he did his best to enter into the spirit for julie’s sake.get/enter into the spirit of
▪ you’ll enjoy yourself much more if you just relax and try to get into the spirit of the occasion.

children.name: to not take part in sth
pull out x
children.definition: pull/drop out/ˌpʊl, ˌdrɒp ˈaʊtǁˌdrɑːp-/ informaltosuddenlydecide not to take part in something, that has already started or is about to start, especially when thiscausesproblems:
examples: rút ra
▪ the show was cancelled when the star unexpectedly pulled out.
▪ by the end of the semester about half of the students had dropped out.
pull/drop out of: rút ra từ cái gì
▪ it’s too late to pull out of the agreement now.
▪ most of the other democratic candidates had already dropped out of the presidential race.

children.name: have nothing to do with b2
children.definition: have nothing to do with/hæv ˌnʌθɪŋ tə ˈduː wɪð/  to not be involved in any way in somethingbadorillegal- use this especially whenotherpeoplethink that you were involved:
examples: chẳng dính dáng gì đến
▪ i’m sure that tony had nothing to do with the robbery.
▪ connie had nothing to do with the break-up of my marriage.
▪ the editor pointed out that he had nothing to do with the discredited advertising campaign.

children.name: play no part in b2
children.definition: take/have/play no part in/ˌteɪk, ˌhæv, ˌpleɪ nəʊ ˈpɑːʳt ɪn/ formaltodeliberatelynot take part in something, because you disagree with it or think it iswrong:
examples: không tham gia
▪ they were pacifists and would take no part in the war.
▪ jen would have no part in forcing gwen out of her job.
▪ i played no part in leaking the information to the press.

children.name: withdraw c1
children.definition: withdraw/wɪðˈdrɔː, wɪθ-/  to decide not to take part in a competition, race, discussion etc, which youpreviouslyagreedto take part in:
examples: rút ra
▪ bower was leading in the polls, but he withdrew when the scandal hit the press.
withdraw from: rút ra từ
▪ clare had to withdraw from the race after injuring her knee.
▪ it will be very sad if jordan withdraws from politics altogether.

children.name: not take part b1
children.definition: not take part/not participate/nɒt teɪk ˈpɑːʳt, nɒt pɑːʳˈtɪspeɪt/ không tham gia/tham dự
examples: ▪ the president was invited to appear on the program but decided not to take part.
▪ we tried to include reggie in the conversation, but he didn’t participate
not take part/not participate in: không tham gia/tham dự vào chuyện gì
▪ party leaders have said they will not take part in the election.
▪ she said that she didn’t participate in the games because her shoulder was sore.
take no further part in[] to stop taking part in sth that you were actively involved in before:ngừng tham gia/tham dự chuyện gì
lineker was injured and took no further part in the game.
schmidt’s lawyer said that he would take no further part in the trial.

children.name: opt out x
children.definition: opt out/ˌɒpt ˈaʊtǁˌɑːpt-/  to decide not to take part in an official system, especially one that has not started yet:không tham gia/tham dự
examples: ▪ employees who do not wish to be part of the company’s healthcare program can opt out if they want to.
opt out of: không tham gia/tham dự cái gì
▪ the treaty gave britain the right to opt out of the single european currency system.

children.name: armchair x
children.definition: armchair/ˈɑːʳmtʃeəʳ, ˌɑːʳmˈtʃeəʳ/  an armchair critic, sportsman, revolutionary etc is someone who does not take part in politics, sport etc but who reads a lot about it or watches it on television, especially someone who thinks they know better than the people doing it and is ready to give them advice:biết nhiều về một lĩnh vực nhưng không có kinh nghiệm thực tế (thánh phán)
examples: ▪ it’s very easy to be an armchair critic but much harder to come up with solutions that will work.
▪ armchair travellers can now visit the world’s most exotic countries via the internet.
▪ like most armchair sportsmen, terry is sure he understands the game better than the referees.

children.name: on the sidelines x
children.definition: on the sidelines/ɒn ðə ˈsaɪdlaɪnz/  if you stay, sit, or wait on the sidelines when something is happening, you do not take part in it, even though you may want to or should do:không dính líu/không tham gia vào (trơ mắt nhìn)
examples: ▪ you can’t just wait on the sidelines and hope things will improve.cậu không thể cứ trơ mắt nhìn rồi hi vọng mọi thứ sẽ có tiến triển
▪ how can we sit on the sidelines when thousands of innocent civilians are being killed.làm sao mà chúng ta có thể trở mắt nhìn khi hàng ngàn đứa trẻ vô tội đang bị giết hại

children.name: to take part in an exam competition, course, etc
enter b1
children.definition: enteralsogo in forsthbritish  to say that you will take part in a competition or race, for example by putting your name on a list:tham gia
examples: ▪ only students under 18 can enter.
▪ dad says he’s going in for the talent contest.
▪ jay and cindy entered the dance competition for fun - they had no idea they would win.
▪ we went in for the crossword competition and won twenty-five pounds.

children.name: take part b1
children.definition: take part/competeb1 to take part in a competition or race: tham gia thi đấu
examples: ▪ only cars over 50 years old are allowed to compete.
▪ the competition was a great success. nearly two hundred people took part.
compete/take part in
▪ how many runners will be competing in the marathon?
▪ please contact debbie if you would like to take part in the charity swim.

children.name: sign up b1
children.definition: sign up/ˌsaɪn ˈʌp/  to arrange to take part in a course of study by signing an agreement: đăng ký
examples: ▪ did you sign up yet? the course starts in two weeks, you know.
sign up for
▪ gary can’t find a job, so he’s signed up for unemployment training.
sign up to do sth
▪ i signed up to take an art class just to get out of the house in the evenings.

children.name: enrol x
children.definition: enrolbritish /enrollamerican /ɪnˈrəʊl/  to formally arrange to take part in a course of study: chiêu nạp, ghi danh, tham gia
examples: ▪ the course is very popular, so it’s best to enrol as soon as possible.
enrol onbritish /+inamerican:
▪ i’d like to enrol on the german course, please.
▪ bill enrolled in a four-year teacher-training course in albany.
enrol forbritish:
▪ that year sam enroled for law studies in cape town.
enrolmentbritish /enrollmentamerican [uncountable noun]
▪ enrollment will take place tomorrow in the main hall between 10:00 and 5:00.

children.name: to not let sb take part
leave out b2
children.definition: leave out to not include someone in an activity or in a group:loại ai ra
examples: ▪ i can’t believe she invited everyone else in the office and left me out.
▪ we meant to include everyone, but we accidentally left out three members.
leave sb out of sth
▪ her husband was always leaving her out of his plans.

children.name: exclude c1
children.definition: exclude/ɪkˈskluːd/  to prevent someone from taking part in an activity, or from joining a group:
examples: loại trừ ai
▪ joe felt sure the others were speaking russian simply to exclude him.
exclude somebody from something: loại trừ ai tra khỏi cái gì
▪ the catholic church continues to exclude women from the priesthood.
▪ stack belongs to a country club that once excluded blacks and jews from membership.
exclusion/ɪkˈskluːʒən/ [uncountable noun]sự loại trừ
the exclusion of somebody from something: sự loại trừ ai ra khỏi cái gì
▪ the exclusion of minorities from the film industry is one of hollywood’s dirty little secrets.

children.name: drop x
children.definition: drop/drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to decide that someone cannolongerbe in a team:loại bỏ
examples: ▪ he couldn’t run fast enough, so the coach dropped him.
drop sb from sth
▪ she was dropped from the badminton team because she missed practice too often.

children.name: when you don't want to take part in sth
want no part in b2
children.definition: want no part inbritish /want no part of somethingamerican /ˌwɒnt nəʊ ˈpɑːʳt ɪn, ˌwɒnt nəʊ ˈpɑːʳt əvǁˌwɑːnt-/  to not want to take part at all in a plan or activity, especially because you disapprove of it:không muốn tham gia/dính líu tới
examples: ▪ i want no part in the deal if drugs are involved.tôi không muốn dính líu gì tới vụ giao dịch này khi nó có dính líu thuốc phiện
▪ the foundation’s conservative leadership made it clear it wanted no part of anything controversial.

children.name: want nothing to do with b2
children.definition: want nothing to do with/wɒnt ˌnʌθɪŋ tə ˈduː wɪð something ǁ wɑːnt-/  to not want to take part in or be involved with something, especially because you disapprove of it:không muốn có dính líu gì
examples: ▪ ‘is robert going to help?’ ‘no, he wants nothing more to do with it.’
▪ a large part of the membership wants nothing to do with the protests and demonstrations.

children.name: leave me out b2
children.definition: leave me out/ count me outspokensay this when you do not want to take part in something which has been suggested:không tính vào /không dính líu
examples: if that’s what you’re going to do, you can count me out.
leave me out. i’d be crazy to get involved in something like that.
i’m sorry, you’ll have to count me out tonight.
scuba diving? oh no, count me out - i hate water!
leave me out of it
you two have to settle it between yourselves - leave me out of it.hai cậu cần phải bình tĩnh và đừng tính tôi vào chuyện này.

children.name: to arrange for sb to take part in an exam, competition, etc
enter b1
children.definition: enter/ˈentəʳ/  to arrange for a person or animal to take part in a competition, race, or examination:đi vào, gia nhập, kết nạp, lấy vào
examples: enter somebody/something in something
▪ your cats are beautiful, have you ever entered them in a cat show?
▪ as part of his training program, lauck has been entered in sunday’s race.
enter somebody/something for something
▪ eight horses were entered for the first race.

children.name: put down b2
children.definition: put sb’s name down/put sb down to arrange for someone to take part in an organized activity by writing their name on a list:đăng kí tham gia/tham dự
examples: ▪ if you think stan would be willing to look after the kids, put his name down.
put sb’s name down/put sb down for
▪ put nancy and her husband down for the banquet - i know they’re planning to come.
put sb’s name down/put sb down to do sth
▪ can we put you down to help with refreshments, carol?

children.name: enrol x
children.definition: enrolbritish /enrollamerican /ɪnˈrəʊl/  to formally arrange for someone to take part in a course of study: ghi danh
examples: enrol onbritish /+inamerican:ghi danh vào cái gì
▪ his parents enrolled him in a military academy when he was only 8.
▪ anybody who has not yet been enrolled on the english course should contact the tutor.

children.name: to get involved with sth you did not want to get involved in
get caught up in c2
children.definition: get caught up in to get involved in something dangerous, unpleasant, or illegal, without wanting to or intending to do this:dính líu (vào một việc nguy hiểm, trái luật)
examples: ▪ i don’t want to get caught up in some petty argument with you.
▪ it is easy for young people to get caught up in crime when there are so few jobs.
▪ one unlucky group of american tourists got caught up in the country’s civil war.

children.name: get drawn into x
children.definition: get drawn into to gradually be persuaded to get involved in sth that you did not intend to get involved in: bị lôi vàos
examples: ▪ u.n. peacekeepers have gotten drawn into the fighting they were trying to prevent.
▪ children who end up on the street are likely to get drawn into prostitution and petty crime.

children.name: get embroiled in x
children.definition: get/become embroiled in to get involved in a long and complicated discussion, argument, or struggle which you do not want to get involved in:tham gia/dính líu vào cái gì
examples: the airline became embroiled in a six-month battle with the pilots’ union.
i don’t want to get embroiled in some endless argument over money.

children.name: to make sb take part in sth
involve b1
children.definition: involve to ask or encourage sb to take part in sth, especially by encouraging them to do this:
examples: ▪ i always try to involve the whole class.
involve sb in sth
▪ a good manager will try to involve everyone in the decision-making process.
▪ the school has gained improved exam results by involving parents more in their children’s education.

children.name: drag sb into x
children.definition: drag sb into to make sb become involved in a situation that they do not want to become involved in, for example an argument or a problem:lôi kéo ai vào việc gì
examples: ▪ don’t go dragging me into your silly family arguments - sort it out yourself.
▪ un troops run the risk of being dragged into local policing problems.

children.name: bring in x
children.definition: bring in to involve sb in an activity that they were not involved in before, especially so that they can provide help or advice: đưa ai vào
examples: ▪ the president brought in ken khachigian to write a speech for the occasion.
▪ the japanese technicians were brought in because of their expertise in electronics.
▪ i don’t think there’s any need to bring the police in until we’re sure the money is missing.

children.name: plunge in c2
children.definition: plunge in/plunge intosthphrasal verb
examples: to suddenly start doing something actively or enthusiastically
two months before his exams, he suddenly plunged into his studies. he took a deep breath and plunged into his speech.

children.name: engage in c2
children.definition: engage insthphrasal verbformal
examples: 1. to take part in something
the two governments have agreed to engage in a comprehensive dialogue to resolve the problem.

children.name: come in c2
children.definition: come inphrasal verbbe involved
examples: 5.informalto become involved in a situation, story or plan
we need expert advice, and that's where you come in.

children.name: association c1
children.definition: associationnouninvolvement
examples: 2. [ u ] when you are involved with or connected to someone or something
her associationwiththe university
this event was organizedinassociationwiththe sports council.

children.name: involvement b2
children.definition: involvement the act of taking part in an activity or event, or the way in which you take part in itsyn participation:
examples: school officials say they welcome parental involvement.
involvement in
his new book examines the united states’ involvement in world war ii.
involvement with
carey’s possible involvement with a series of robberies

children.name: in b1
children.definition: inprepositioninvolved
examples: 13. involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
i never knew you were in publishing.
a degree in philosophy
advances in medical science

children.name: participation x
children.definition: participation/pɑːʳˌtɪsɪˈpeɪʃən, pɑːʳˌtɪsəˈpeɪʃən/  when people participate:sự tham dự/tham gia
examples: ▪ the play was produced for children and encourages audience participation.
participation in : dự tham gia/tham dự vào cái gì
▪our partners are demanding full participation in the decision-making process.

children.name: contribute b2
children.definition: contribute/kənˈtrɪbjuːt/  to actively take part in a group discussion or group activity, especially by giving your opinions and ideas:đóng góp
examples: ▪ when we have class debates we try and get all the kids to contribute.
▪ during the discussions macdonald seemed to be listening, but he had nothing to contribute.
contribute ideas/suggestions etc
▪ readers are invited to contribute their opinions on any of the issues discussed here.

children.name: appear on
children.definition: /əˈpɪər ɒn/  to take part in a tv or radio programme:xuất hiện trên (chương trình tv hoặc đài)
examples: ▪ forbes appeared on ‘meet the press’ to discuss recent political developments.
▪ he has often appeared on the bbc sports programme ‘a question of sport’.
appearance[countable noun]sự xuất hiện
▪ the six-year-old’s talents earned him an appearance on the oprah winfrey show.

children.name: hands-on x
children.definition: hands-on involving doing or learning about something by taking part in it yourself, rather than just watching, reading about it, or hearing about it from someone else: thực hành
examples: ▪ the training programs give students practical hands-on experience.
▪ the exhibit includes numerous hands-on activities, including several archaeological dig stations.
▪ mr garvey is known as a hands-on manager with an in-depth knowledge of the whole company.

children.name: when you want to take part in sth
count me in c2
children.definition: count mein informal to include sb in an activity or arrangement
examples: "do you want to come swimming tomorrow?" "yes, count me in."
when the game gets started, you can count me in.
